026package com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.patterns;
027
028import java.util.concurrent.Callable;
029import java.util.concurrent.ScheduledFuture;
030import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
031
032import com.ibm.streams.operator.AbstractOperator;
033import com.ibm.streams.operator.OperatorContext;
034import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.InputPortSet;
035import com.ibm.streams.operator.model.Parameter;
036
037/**
038 * Abstract pattern class for an operator that produces tuples
039 * (a <em>source operator</em>) and typically does not
040 * support input ports. This class provides support for an initial
041 * delay, allowing submission of tuples to occur a period of time
042 * after {@link #allPortsReady()} is called by the SPL runtime.
043 * This class calls the abstract method {@link #startProcessing()}
044 * to indicate to the sub-class that it can begin to submit tuples.
045 * <P>
046 * If the operator parameter {@link #setInitDelay(long) initDelay} is set then it is taken as the
047 * number of seconds before {@link #startProcessing()} is called. <BR>
048 * The initial delay can also be set using the methods on this class to allow
049 * delays to be specified in different units.
050 * </P>
051 * <P>
052 * While source operators typically do not have input ports, sub-classes
053 * may support input ports and implement
054 * {@link #process(com.ibm.streams.operator.StreamingInput, com.ibm.streams.operator.Tuple) tuple processing}.
055 * Typically these input ports are {@link InputPortSet#controlPort() control ports} that allow
056 * updates how the operator fetches its tuples as changing a database connection string.
057 * </P>
058 */
059public abstract class TupleProducer extends AbstractOperator {
060
061    private long initialDelay = 0;
062    private TimeUnit initialDelayUnit = TimeUnit.SECONDS;
063
064    /**
065     * ScheduledFuture of the call to startProcessing() when the initial delay
066     * is non-zero.
067     */
068    private ScheduledFuture<?> startProcessingFuture;
069
070    /**
071     * {@inheritDoc}
072    */
073    @Override
074    public void initialize(OperatorContext context)
075            throws Exception {
076        super.initialize(context);
077
078        producerInitialize();
079    }
080    
081    /**
082     * Set the initial delay from the operator parameter
083     * {@code initDelay} in seconds.
084     * @param delaySeconds Delay in seconds before starting processing.
085     */
086    @Parameter(optional=true,
087            description="Delay in seconds before the operator starts producing tuples.")
088    public void setInitDelay(long delaySeconds) {
089        setInitialDelay(delaySeconds, TimeUnit.SECONDS);
090    }
091    
092    /**
093     * Set the initial delay in seconds.
094     * This method may be used by sub-classes to provide
095     * an {@code initDelay} parameter of type {@code float64}.
096     * This is achieved by hiding {@link #setInitDelay(long)}
097     * in the sub-class and create a public
098     * annotated version of {@link #setInitDelay(double)}.
099     * <pre>
100     * <code>
101     * // hide the version annotated with {@literal @}Parameter
102     * public void setInitDelay(long delay) { super.setInitDelay(delay); }
103     * 
104     * // Annotated version to create an initDelay parameter of type float64.
105     * {@literal @}Parameter(optional=true,
106            description="Delay in seconds before the operator starts producing tuples.")
107     * public void setInitDelay(double delay) { super.setInitDelay(delay); }
108     * </code>
109     * </pre>
110     * 
111     * @param delaySeconds Delay in seconds before starting processing. This is converted to milliseconds
112     * resulting in a call to
113     * {@link #setInitialDelay(long, TimeUnit) setInitialDelay(delaySeconds * 1000.0, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)}. 
114     */
115    protected void setInitDelay(double delaySeconds) {
116        long delayms = (long) (delaySeconds * 1000.0);
117        this.setInitialDelay(delayms, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);
118    }
119
120    /**
121     * {@inheritDoc}
122     * <P>
123     * Calls {@link #startProcessing()} method immediately if
124     * initial delay is zero, otherwise asynchronously calls
125     * {@code startProcessing()} after the required
126     * initial delay.
127     * </P>
128     */
129    @Override
130    public synchronized void allPortsReady() throws Exception {
131
132        if (getInitialDelay() == 0) {
133            startProcessing();
134            return;
135        }
136
137        // Kick off asynchronously a call to startProcessing() after the initial
138        // delay has expired.
139        startProcessingFuture = getOperatorContext()
140                .getScheduledExecutorService().schedule(new Callable<Object>() {
141
142                    public Object call() throws Exception {
143                        startProcessing();
144                        return null;
145                    }
146                }, getInitialDelay(), getInitialDelayUnit());
147    }
148
149    /**
150     * Initialize this operator. Called during <code>initialize()</code>.
151     * @deprecated Sub-classes should instead override {@link #initialize(OperatorContext)}
152     * to be consistent with {@link AbstractOperator}.
153     * 
154     * @see AbstractOperator#initialize(OperatorContext)
155     */
156    @Deprecated
157    protected void producerInitialize() throws Exception {
158    }
159
160    /**
161     * Cancel the startProcessing() task if it was asynchronously kicked off due
162     * to an initial delay and has not yet started.
163     * <P>
164     * Sub-classes <b>must</b> call
165     * <code>super.shutdown()</code> if they override this method.
166     * </P>
167     */
168    public synchronized void shutdown() throws Exception {
169
170        if (startProcessingFuture != null) {
171            if (!startProcessingFuture.isDone())
172                startProcessingFuture.cancel(true);
173        }
174        super.shutdown();
175    }
176
177    /**
178     * Get the initial delay. The default value is 0 but is overwritten by the
179     * value (in seconds) of the initDelay parameter. The initDelay parameter is
180     * read prior to {@link #initialize(OperatorContext)}.
181     * 
182     * @return Value of the initial delay.
183     */
184    public final synchronized long getInitialDelay() {
185        return initialDelay;
186    }
187
188    /**
189     * Get the unit of the initial delay. Defaults to SECONDS.
190     * 
191     * @return Unit for the initial delay.
192     */
193    public final synchronized TimeUnit getInitialDelayUnit() {
194        return initialDelayUnit;
195    }
196
197    /**
198     * Set the initial delay for processing tuples from the external source.
199     * Sub-classes may call this from {@link #initialize(OperatorContext)} to override the
200     * default.
201     * 
202     * @param initialDelay Value for the initial delay
203     * @param unit Unit for {@code initialDelay}.
204     */
205    public final synchronized void setInitialDelay(long initialDelay,
206            TimeUnit unit) {
207        this.initialDelay = initialDelay;
208        this.initialDelayUnit = unit;
209    }
210
211    /**
212     * Called to indicate that the operator can start submitting tuples.
213     * It will be called after any configured initial delay.
214     * This method is required to return immediately to the SPL
215     * runtime, by starting the processing to fetch tuples asynchronously,
216     * this may be achieved using the OperatorContext's ScheduledExecutorService
217     * or starting a thread created using the OperatorContext's ThreadFactory
218     * during producerInitialize().
219     * 
220     */
221    protected abstract void startProcessing() throws Exception;
222}
